Pollution of surface water and groundwater with ClO4 – is serious problem. Catalytic reduction of ClO4 – with H2 is an ideal method because harmless Cl– is the only product. In this study, we evaluated catalytic performances of seven metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Re, Ir, Pt, and Ni) supported on Al2O3 for reduction of ClO4 – with H2 at 353 K. Among them, only Ru/Al2O3 exhibited a decent activity for the reaction. To improve the catalytic performance, we investigated support effect and found that CeO2 was the best support owing to the high dispersion of Ru. Ru/CeO2 did not lose any activity even in neutral and weakly basic solutions, which is a great advantage for practical applications. Kinetic analysis and reactivity tests of possible intermediates over Ru/CeO2 in the presence and absence of H2 revealed that the reduction of ClO4 – proceeded successively through ClO3 – and then ClO2 –, and ClO2 – disproportionated to Cl–. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Perchlorate Ruthenium Ceria Water purification Reaction pathway Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Since perchlorate (ClO4 –) has a strong oxidizability and a high reactivity, it is used as a raw material for rocket propellant, explosives, and fireworks [1,2]. Nevertheless, low concentrations of ClO4 – in water are highly stable. Due to its high solubility in water and low adsorbability to natural solids, ClO4 – is difficult to remove from water by adsorption in the natural environment. Thus, improper storage and treatment of products and wastes containing ClO4 – cause serious environmental pollution. In fact, recently ClO4 – has been found in surface water and groundwater in various areas [1]. ClO4 – taken in the body inhibits iodide uptake by the thyroid gland, which leads to suppression of the production of thyroid hormones [3,4]. Since thyroid hormones are involved in the development of the central nervous system, deleterious effects from ClO4 – have appeared especially for fetuses and infants. Therefore, the U.S. EPA has listed ClO4 – on the drinking water contaminant candidate lists, and an allowable concentration of 15 μg L–1 has been set for drinking water [4]. In Japan, tap water is being tested for ClO4 –, and a concentration of 25 μg L–1 or less has been recommended. So far, various methods, including ion exchange, adsorption, reverse osmosis, ultrafiltration, and electrodialysis, have been investigated toward the purification of ClO4 –-polluted water. However, since those methods are used to remove ClO4 –, wastewater with high concentrations of ClO4 – are inevitably generated and, thus, require further treatment. In contrast, biological treatment and catalytic and electrocatalytic reductions can be used to decompose ClO4 – into harmless Cl–. Catalytic and electrocatalytic reductions are preferred because biological treatment is unsuitable for small purification systems and intermittent operation. Catalytic reduction of ClO4 – with H2 over heterogeneous catalysts is an ideal method because harmless Cl– and H2O are the only products of the reaction (Eq. 1), although the problem of handling hydrogen gas remains when it is practically applied. (1) ClO4 – + 4 H2 → Cl– + 4 H2O In 1995, Abu-Omar and Espenson reported that oxygen transfer occurred from ClO4 – to a Re(V) complex to afford a Re(VII) complex and ClO3 – in aqueous solutions at pH 0 [5]. Moreover, they demonstrated that the Re(VII) complex was reduced back to the original Re(V) with hypophosphorous acid (H3PO2) [6]. Hurley and Shapley have found that Re-Pd/carbon prepared by fixing Re(VII) compound (either ammonium perrhenate or methylrhenium trioxide) on Pd/carbon under hydrogen atmosphere promotes the catalytic reduction of ClO4 – to Cl– with 1 atm H2 at room temperature [7]. They have improved the catalytic performance of Re-Pd/carbon by modifying it with dimethylaminopyridine, which coordinates to the active Re center [8]. Furthermore, they report that Re-Pd/carbon prepared by fixing [Re(O)(hoz)2]+ (hoz = 2-(2′-hydroxyphenyl)− 2-oxazoline) on Pd/carbon under hydrogen atmosphere is more than 10 times more active than previously reported Re-Pd/carbon catalysts [9]. However, the Re-Pd catalysts have a drawback in that they lose catalytic activity in weakly acidic to neutral solutions, whereas they show very high activity in strong acidic solution at pH 3 or lower [7–10]. This is because activation of ClO4 – on a Re(V) site by a proton-mediated hydrogen bond (ClO4 –···H+···Re(V)) does not occur effectively in neutral solution. Recently, Liu and co-workers have developed a Mo-Pd/carbon material modified with 2,2′-bipyridine which shows high catalytic activity for the reduction of ClO4 – with H2 in water [11,12]. However, the catalytic performance decreases even in weakly acidic solution (pH 4.7) [11]. For practical applications of this catalytic method to purify polluted water, the catalysts must be active in neutral water. Inspired by the natural metalloenzyme perchlorate reductase [13], homogeneous catalysts with Fe [14,15] and Mo [16] active for the oxygen transfer reaction of ClO4 – have been developed. Although the catalysts effectively promote the reaction, the catalytic performances have been evaluated only in organic solution, and special reducing agents, like 1,2-diphenylhydrazine and triphenyl phosphine, are necessary for regeneration of the oxidized active center. This is unsuitable for water purification. Wang et al. have screened 78 metals for catalytic reduction of ClO4 – with H2 in water near room temperature, and they report that tungsten carbide, Pd/carbon, and Raney Ni exhibit catalytic activity [17]. However, the reaction rates are extremely low and, thus, unsatisfactory for practical applications. In general, precious metal (e.g. Pt) and some base metal (e.g. Ni) catalysts effectively activate H2 to give atomic H on the catalyst and consequently act as hydrogenation catalysts. Thus, we thought that those catalysts had the potential to act as a catalyst for the reduction of ClO4 – with H2 if ClO4 – was properly activated on them. A viable and simple way to improve the activation is to carry out the reaction at somewhat high reaction temperatures but not too high for water purification. In the present study, we screened six precious metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Re, Ir, and Pt) and one base metal (Ni) as an active component for the catalytic reduction of ClO4 – with 1 atm H2 in water at 353 K, and we found that a Ru catalyst showed high catalytic activity for the reaction even in neutral solution. To improve the catalytic performance of the supported Ru catalysts, we further investigated the effects of the support material and loading amount of Ru on the catalytic performances. In addition, the reaction pathway for the reduction of ClO4 – to Cl– over the supported Ru catalyst based on reactivity of possible intermediates (ClO x –, x = 1, 2, and 3) over the catalyst and reaction kinetics is proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO2-supported Ru with 3 wt% Ru was prepared as follows. RuCl3·nH2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.) was dissolved in Milli-Q water to obtain an aqueous solution with 0.167 mol L–1 Ru. To 2 g of CeO2 (Reference Catalyst of the Catalysis Society of Japan, JRC-CEO-3), 3.67 mL of the solution was added little by little. After the powder was fully wetted, it was dried at 333 K for 30 min. This operation was repeated until all the solution was added. The resulting solid was dried at 373 K for 10 h and calcined in air at 573 K for 3 h. Just before catalytic reaction, the catalyst was reduced with H2 at 723 K for 2 h. Unless otherwise mentioned, 3 wt% Ru/CeO2 was used and is noted Ru/CeO2. At the same time, 1 and 5 wt% Ru/CeO2 were prepared using a similar procedure. Supported Ru catalysts with different support materials were prepared using a similar procedure as that for Ru/CeO2. However, Al2O3 (Nippon Aerosil Co., Ltd., Aeroixde® AluC), SiO2 (Nippon Aerosil Co., Ltd., Aerosil® 300), TiO2 (Nippon Aerosil Co., Ltd., Aeroixde® P25) and active carbon (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co., Wako Special Grade) were used instead of CeO2. Al2O3-supported Ni, Rh, Pd, Re, Ir, and Pt were prepared using an impregnation method similar to that for Ru/CeO2 with Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), RhCl3·3 H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), PdCl2 (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), NH4ReO4 (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), IrCl3 (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), and H2PtCl6·6 H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), respectively. 2.2 Characterization Powder XRD patterns were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, D2 PHASER) with Cu Kα radiation. The amount of chemisorbed CO was measured at 323 K by using a CO-pulse method with an automatic instrument (BEL Japan Inc., BEL CAT). Prior to the measurement, the sample was pretreated in H2 at 723 K for 2 h. 2.3 Catalytic reduction of ClO4 – with H2 in water Reaction solutions (1 mmol L–1, 100 mg L–1) were prepared using KClO4 (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.). The pH of the reaction solutions was adjusted to 2, 4, 7, and 9 by adding dilute hydrochloric acid or aqueous sodium hydroxide. The reaction solution (100 mL) and catalyst (0.1 g), which was reduced with H2 at 723 K in advance, were put in a three-necked flask, and the flask was soaked in a water bath. After the temperature of the reaction solution reached to 353 K, 10 mL min–1 of H2 was continuously fed into the reaction solution. A small portion of the reaction solution was taken at 1, 3, 6, and 24 h and was centrifuged to separate the catalyst. The concentrations of ClO4 – and products in the supernatant were determined using two ion chromatographs. For ClO4 –, an ion chromatograph (Thermo Scientific, Dionex CS-900) equipped with a Dionex IonPac AS16 IC column and a suppresser unit (Thermo Scientific, AMMS 300) was used with an aqueous NaOH solution as the eluent. For ClO3 –, ClO2 –, ClO–, and Cl–, an ion chromatograph (Tosoh Co., IC-2001) equipped with a TSKgel® SuperIC-AZ column was used with an aqueous solution of NaHCO3 and Na2CO3 as the eluent. However, Cl– was the only product regardless of the catalysts and reaction conditions. Hydrogenations of ClO3 –, ClO2 – and ClO– were performed under similar conditions to those for ClO4 –. However, KClO3 (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), NaClO2 (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), and NaClO solutions (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Co.), respectively, were used instead of a KClO4 solution. Only for 3 wt% Ru/CeO2, which was the most active catalyst among the catalysts tested in the study, a long-term reaction test was performed in a gas-liquid continuous flow reactor (Pyrex tube, 10 mm i.d.). The temperature of the reactor was maintained at 353 K in a water bath. An aqueous solution of ClO4 – (0.5 mmol L–1, 1 mL min–1) and H2 (10 mL min–1) was fed into the reactor filled with the catalyst (0.5 g) under atmospheric pressure. The liquid phase was periodically collected at the end of the reactor and analyzed with the ion chromatographs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performances of supported Ru catalysts Fig. 1 shows a comparison of the catalytic performances of Al2O3-supported metal catalysts for the reduction of ClO4 –. pH of the reaction solution and the reaction time were 4 and 24 h, respectively. Rh, Pd, Re, Ir, and Pt catalysts showed no or only low activity for the reaction. The conversion using Ni/Al2O3 was 16% at 24 h. However, it was not due to the decomposition of ClO4 – by the reaction with H2 because no product (ClO3 –, ClO2 –, ClO–, and Cl–) was detected, and the conversion of ClO4 – did not increase after 1 h (data is not shown), indicating that adsorption of ClO4 – on Ni/Al2O3 occurred. On the other hand, the conversion using Ru/Al2O3 was 71%, and an amount of Cl– equivalent to the amount of decomposed ClO4 – formed as a product. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report where a supported Ru catalyst has been shown to promote the reduction of ClO4 – with H2. To improve the catalytic performance, the effects of the support for Ru catalysts were investigated. Fig. 2 shows conversions of ClO4 – at 6 h over supported Ru catalysts with different supports. The catalytic performances were evaluated in reaction solutions at pH 4 and 7. Although all Ru catalysts showed activity for the reaction at pH 4, Ru/CeO2 was the best, and Ru/active carbon was the second best. For the reactions at pH 7, the support effects were more pronounced than those at pH 4. The conversion was low when Ru/SiO2, Ru/TiO2, and Ru/Al2O3 were used at pH 7. To investigate the reason for the difference in the catalytic activities due to the support materials, dispersions of Ru in the catalysts were evaluated on the basis of the amount of chemisorbed CO at 323 K, assuming that the ratio of adsorbed CO to surface Ru atoms was one. The results indicated that the dispersions of Ru in Ru/CeO2 (44%) and Ru/active carbon (33%) were high, whereas those for the catalysts with low activities, including Ru/SiO2, Ru/TiO2, and Ru/Al2O3, were 5% or less. Thus, a reason for the high catalytic activities of Ru/CeO2 and Ru/active carbon is the formation of small Ru particles on those supports, leading to the large number of Ru sites exposed on the surface. In fact, no diffraction line due to Ru0 crystallites was observed in the powder XRD pattern for Ru/CeO2, and only a very weak and broad diffraction line attributable to Ru0 crystallite was found in the pattern for Ru/active carbon (Fig. S1), which supports the fact that Ru was highly dispersed on CeO2 and active carbon. Next, the catalytic performance of Ru/CeO2 was evaluated in reaction solutions at pH 2, 4, 7 and 9 to demonstrate the usefulness of the catalyst for a wide range of pH values, especially in neutral solution. As shown in Fig. 3, the catalytic performance of Ru/CeO2 was almost the same in the solutions at pH 4, 7, and 9. In other words, Ru/CeO2 is useful even in neutral and weakly basic solutions, implying that a proton-mediated hydrogen bond is not involved in the activation of ClO4 – on the Ru sites, unlike Re catalysts [7–10]. The severe catalyst deactivation observed for the reaction solution at pH 2 is thought to be due to aggregation of the catalyst powder (Fig. S2). The aggregated catalyst was collected and added to a reaction solution at pH 7. However, the catalyst never redispersed in the solution and showed only low catalytic activity, suggesting irreversible change in the catalyst surface in the solution at pH 2. The loading amount of Ru on CeO2 was investigated. In Fig. 4, time-course changes during the conversion of ClO4 – for the reaction over Ru/CeO2 at pH 7 with different Ru loadings are shown. Bare CeO2 was completely inactive. The activity increased with an increase in the Ru loading up to 3 wt%. However, excess Ru, namely 5 wt% Ru, caused a huge decrease in the activity, probably due to the formation of large Ru particles. Therefore, 3 wt% Ru was the optimal Ru loading for Ru/CeO2. To confirm the heterogenous catalysis of Ru/CeO2, a hot-filtration experiment was performed ( Fig. 5). At 1 h of the reaction, the catalyst powder was removed from the reaction solution by filtration while the solution was hot, and the resulting solution was heated again at 353 K in H2 to continue the reaction. As the results clearly show, there was no reaction without the catalyst, indicating that there was no homogeneous catalytic activity due to a dissolved Ru species. To investigate the stability of Ru/CeO2, a long-term reaction test was performed in a fixed-bed continuous reactor. The results are shown in Fig. 6. From the beginning to around 4 h, the conversion significantly decreased and then gradually decreased with time. After 20 h, the performance became nearly stable. Since Ru was not detected in the reaction solution at the outlet of the reactor, which was checked by ICP-AES, dissolution of Ru was not a reason for the catalyst deactivation. Thus, it was speculated that sintering of Ru in the initial stage of the reaction was a main cause for the deactivation. Table 1 shows a comparison of the catalytic performances of our Ru/CeO2 with those of previously reported catalysts. Since the catalytic performances were evaluated at around room temperature in the previous papers [7,8,10,17], that of Ru/CeO2 was evaluated at 298 K, and the results are included in Table 1. Although Ru/CeO2 showed high catalytic activity even in neutral solution at 353 K, the reaction rate was significantly lower at 298 K but was still higher than those over DMAP modified ReO x -Pd/carbon at pH 7 [8], which was obtained by extrapolating pH-dependence data to pH 7, and Re-complex-Pd/carbon catalyst at pH 6 [10]. 3.2 Reaction pathway for the reduction of ClO 4 – over Ru/CeO 2 Fig. 7 shows time-course changes in the concentrations of ClO4 – and products obtained from the reduction of ClO4 – with H2 over Ru/CeO2 performed in a batch reactor. The concentration of ClO4 – gradually decreased with time, whereas that of Cl– increased. No product other than Cl– was detected over the entire reaction time. The mass balance of Cl calculated from the concentrations of ClO4 – and Cl– remained almost 100% over the reaction time. The fact that no intermediate product was detected indicated that the reduction of ClO4 – to ClO3 – was a rate-determining step. To further investigate the reaction pathway, the reactivities of the possible intermediates, including ClO3 –, ClO2 –, and ClO–, over Ru/CeO2 in the presence of H2 were evaluated and compared with that of ClO4 –. Fig. 8 shows a comparison of the reactivities of each reactant. The conversion of ClO4 – was about 50% at 1 h, and that of ClO3 – was 99%. This result clearly indicates that ClO3 – is more reactive than ClO4 –, which is consistent with that the reduction of ClO4 – to ClO3 – was the rate-determining step. The reactivity of ClO2 – was much higher than that of ClO3 –, and the conversion of ClO2 – reached 100% in just 5 min. In contrast to ClO2 – and ClO3 –, the reactivity of ClO– was lower than that of ClO4 –. If the reduction of ClO4 – proceeded consecutively through ClO–, it must be detected during the reduction of ClO4 –. However, the fact was that no ClO– was detected over the reaction time indicates that the reaction pathway does not proceed through ClO– to Cl–. To confirm the above, time-course changes for the reaction of ClO2 – over Ru/CeO2 in the presence of H2 were investigated ( Fig. 9). As mentioned above, ClO2 – completely reacted within 5 min, and ClO3 – and Cl– formed in a 2:1 ratio. After that, the concentration of ClO3 –gradually decreased with time, and that of Cl– increased. To check if disproportionation of ClO2 – (3ClO2 – → 2ClO3 – + Cl–) occurred over Ru/CeO2, the reaction of ClO2 – was performed in a flow of N2 without H2. The ClO2 – completely reacted within 5 min, giving ClO3 – and Cl– in a 2:1 ratio. In contrast to the reaction with H2, the concentrations of ClO3 – and Cl– did not change with prolonged reaction time (data is not shown). ClO2 – did not react in the presence of bare CeO2. These results show that disproportionation of ClO2 – occurs quickly on the Ru sites over Ru/CeO2. On the basis of these results, we propose a reaction pathway for the reduction of ClO4 – with H2 over Ru/CeO2 shown in Scheme 1. In the first step, ClO4 – is reduced to ClO3 –, which is the rate-determining step. The ClO3 – is then reduced to ClO2 –, which promptly undergoes disproportionation to give Cl– on the Ru sites. The reaction pathway does not include ClO– as an intermediate. 4 Conclusion The catalytic performances of six precious metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Re, Ir, and Pt) and one base metal (Ni) were evaluated with Al2O3-supported catalysts for the catalytic reduction of ClO4 – with 1 atm H2 at 353 K. Among the metals, only Ru showed decent activity for the reaction. The catalytic performance of the supported Ru catalyst varied greatly depending on the carriers, and CeO2 was the best one due to the formation of highly dispersed Ru particles. Ru/CeO2 was highly active in the reaction solution in the pH range of 4–9, which is a great advantage for practical applications in water purification. The reduction of ClO4 – with H2 over Ru/CeO2 proceeded successively through ClO3 – and ClO2 –. ClO2 – quickly underwent disproportionation to afford Cl–, i.e., 3ClO2 – → 2ClO3 – + Cl–, and no ClO– was involved in the reaction. coredata.dc:description: Pollution of surface water and groundwater with ClO4 – is serious problem. Catalytic reduction of ClO4 – with H2 is an ideal method because harmless Cl– is the only product. In this study, we evaluated catalytic performances of seven metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Re, Ir, Pt, and Ni) supported on Al2O3 for reduction of ClO4 – with H2 at 353 K. Among them, only Ru/Al2O3 exhibited a decent activity for the reaction. To improve the catalytic performance, we investigated support effect and found that CeO2 was the best support owing to the high dispersion of Ru. Ru/CeO2 did not lose any activity even in neutral and weakly basic solutions, which is a great advantage for practical applications. Kinetic analysis and reactivity tests of possible intermediates over Ru/CeO2 in the presence and absence of H2 revealed that the reduction of ClO4 – proceeded successively through ClO3 – and then ClO2 –, and ClO2 – disproportionated to Cl–.
coredata.dc:title: Reduction of perchlorate in neutral water over a ceria-supported ruthenium catalyst towards the purification of contaminated water
